channel.title: We're not ready. But we never have been.
channel.description: We're not ready. But we never have been.

item.title: The trouble with big data? It's called the 'recency bias'
item.description:
The trouble with big data? It's called the 'recency bias'

You may be familiar with the statistic that 90% of the world's data was created in the last few years. It's true. One of the first mentions of this particular formulation I can find dates back to May 2013, but the trend remains remarkably constant.

item.title: Why Did I Implant A Chip In My Hand?
item.description:
Why Did I Implant A Chip In My Hand?

A few months ago, in the expo-hall of the Austin Convention Center, I laid my left hand flat on a sheet of sterile paper and let a very tall, friendly man insert an RFID chip into the space between my thumb and index finger.

item.title: Can Urban Highways Solve Problems Instead Of Causing Them?
item.description:
Can Urban Highways Solve Problems Instead Of Causing Them?

Los Angeles is known for its freeways, and that's not a good thing. But while some cities are starting to tear sections of highway down-reconnecting neighborhoods and rebuilding pedestrian culture-that tends to happen in places where the roads are underused.

item.title: Robot Performs Soft-Tissue Surgery By Itself
item.description:
Robot Performs Soft-Tissue Surgery By Itself

With a bulky camera eye and spindly hydraulic arm, this medical robot looks like it could fit in on an automotive production line. This bot isn't building a Toyota, though. It carefully scans soft, sticky intestinal tissue and delicately weaves stitches with unmatched surgical precision.

item.title: Dear Google, the future is fewer people writing code
item.description:
Dear Google, the future is fewer people writing code

Google recently launched Project Bloks - a "platform" that will enable developers, educators and designers to work together in order to build "physical programming experiences" for children. This actually has the potential to be a great educational tool - but not in the way Google presents it (or at least not in the way it's being written about).

item.title: This Cybernetic Lifeform Is Powered by Plant Intelligence
item.description:
This Cybernetic Lifeform Is Powered by Plant Intelligence

The robotic geodesic sphere seen inching along Hampstead road in London. Image: William Victor Camilleri Cities like London can often feel like urban jungles with scarce amounts of green spaces. But researchers from the Interactive Architecture Lab at University College London are exploring a future scenario where "cybernetic lifeforms" that are "half garden and half machine" roam our urban cityscapes, co-existing alongside us.

item.title: Here's What We'd Look Like If We Were Built to Withstand Car Crashes - Motor Trend
item.description:
Here's What We'd Look Like If We Were Built to Withstand Car Crashes - Motor Trend

Some would call him strange, others would call him superhuman. His official name is Graham, and he's the only person specifically designed to survive a car crash.An accident research engineer, a trauma surgeon, and a Melbourne artist joined forces to create Graham, a vision of what humans would be like had we evolved to withstand ...

item.title: Humans will live underwater in 100 years' time as the population is squeezed out of cities
item.description:
Humans will live underwater in 100 years' time as the population is squeezed out of cities

The SmartThings Future Living Report suggests that in a century's time, we'll be living underwater because land space in urban areas will be in short supply. Underwater neighbourhoods and floating communities will spring up, while building deeper into the earth will also become a priority.

item.title: Surprisingly efficient snail brains could help make robots smarter
item.description:
Surprisingly efficient snail brains could help make robots smarter

Searching for (and consuming food) is a surprisingly complex goal-directed behavior, essential for survival. It appears snails are particularly efficient at processing these decisions. According to Kemenes, the study was also able to show "how this system helps to manage how much energy they use once they have made a decision."
